title: Sistem Pencarian Forum Berbasis Ontologi Dan Label
abstract: Salah satu kegiatan yang sering dilakukan pengguna internet adalah berdiskusi melalui sebuah forum. Setiap forum terbagi ke dalam beberapa kategori, dan setiap kategori memiliki beberapa percakapan (thread). Setiap percakapan dapat diberi label (tag) baik oleh pengguna yang membuka percakapan tersebut, atau peserta forum. Masalah yang muncul adalah bila sebuah forum telah menjadi besar mencari percakapan yang tepat yang sesuai kebutuhan pengguna menjadi lebih sulit. Penelitian ini bertujuan mengusulkan metode rekomendasi percakapan di sebuah forum internet yang menggunakan label dan didukung oleh ontologi yang sesuai dengan kategori percakapan. Penelitian ini mengkhususkan pada forum dengan kategori teknologi komputer. Forum tersebut adalah StackOverflow. Pada setiap percakapan pada forum tersebut terdapat label-label yang menjelaskan isi percakapan, misalnya C#, recursive, programming, dll. Label-label tersebut dikembangkan (diperbanyak) menggunakan ontologi komputer. Hasilnya adalah setiap percakapan akan diwakili oleh label-label asli dari StackOverflow, dan ditambah dengan label-label baru yang berasal dari ontologi. Label-label tersebut digunakan dalam proses pencarian berbasis Vector Space Model (VSM). Hasil penelitian menunjukkan bahwa penggunaan ontologi sebagai metode keyword extension meningkatkan nilai recall dari metode VSM tersebut.

title: Natural Language Processing for Automated Essay Scoring
abstract: This study explores the application of natural language processing techniques for automated essay scoring. Traditional methods of essay assessment are time-consuming and subject to human bias. We propose a machine learning approach that analyzes linguistic features, semantic coherence, and grammatical structure to provide consistent and objective scoring. Our model incorporates word embeddings, syntactic parsing, and discourse analysis to evaluate essays across multiple dimensions. Experimental results on a dataset of 10,000 student essays show that our approach achieves a correlation of 0.85 with human graders, outperforming existing automated systems. This research has significant implications for educational assessment, potentially reducing grading workload while maintaining evaluation quality.

title: Blockchain-Based Framework for Secure Health Records
abstract: Electronic health records face challenges related to security, privacy, and interoperability. This research proposes a blockchain-based framework to address these issues while ensuring patient data remains accessible to authorized healthcare providers. Our approach implements smart contracts to manage access control and uses a permissioned blockchain network to maintain an immutable audit trail of all data access events. We incorporate homomorphic encryption to enable computation on encrypted data, allowing analytics without compromising privacy. The framework was evaluated in a simulated healthcare environment with 5,000 patient records across 12 healthcare providers. Results demonstrate a 99.7% reduction in unauthorized access attempts and improved interoperability between disparate systems without sacrificing performance.

title: Computer Vision Techniques for Urban Traffic Management
abstract: This paper presents a novel computer vision system for real-time urban traffic monitoring and management. Traditional traffic management relies on physical sensors embedded in roadways, which are expensive to install and maintain. Our proposed system uses a network of cameras combined with deep learning algorithms to detect, track, and classify vehicles. The framework incorporates adaptive background modeling, multi-object tracking, and convolutional neural networks for vehicle classification. We deployed our system at 15 key intersections in a metropolitan area for six months. The system achieved 94.8% accuracy in vehicle counting and 91.2% accuracy in classification under varying weather and lighting conditions. The implementation reduced congestion by 27% and average wait times by 32% when integrated with traffic signal control systems.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Optimizing Energy Consumption in Smart Buildings
abstract: Energy efficiency in buildings represents a significant challenge in reducing global carbon emissions. This research investigates the application of reinforcement learning algorithms to optimize HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) operations in smart buildings. We developed a deep Q-learning model that considers multiple variables including occupancy patterns, weather forecasts, thermal properties of the building, and electricity pricing. The system continuously learns from its environment to maintain comfort levels while minimizing energy consumption. Our approach was implemented in three commercial buildings over a 12-month period, resulting in energy savings of 21-34% compared to traditional control systems. The model demonstrated adaptability to seasonal changes and varying occupancy patterns without sacrificing occupant comfort. This research contributes to sustainable building management practices with potential for significant energy conservation at scale.
